Saw this in another team’s pits at AZ East, had to take a picture. Would there be any good use for an omni swerve module? It seems like the worst of both worlds to me.
I don’t remember what team it was, btw.

I am just totally lost here…

I get using this on a tank…not on a swerve. To me, as uneducated in swerve, this defeats the purpose of sorts. It would be easy to push this bot around…and it shouldn’t be able to get on the climbing station…or it would need help.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T20:03:20.797Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":623,"readers_count":622,"score":264.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431008,"topic_slug":"omni-swerve","display_username":"Ben Edwards","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37435,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"EE mentor"},"post_url":"/t/omni-swerve/431008/3","custom_user_title":"EE mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3168826,"name":"Dustin Benedict","username":"thefro526","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thefro526/{size}/2228_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T20:04:34.109Z","cooked":"

There was actually a case where this makes sense - at least if you look historically.

Swerve drives with 4 wheel independent steering and power are relatively new in the history of FRC - prior to 2013-2014, it wasn’t uncommon to see common steering / common power swerve drives that often needed to do something special to “Turn”.

It wouldn’t surprise me to see someone still doing this in 2023 - arguably it is “easier” with respect to software and kinematics - though with that being said, these problems have been solved for a while.

(Fwiw, part of the mass proliferation of swerve has been that it’s now possible to devote 8 motors to your drive train with no real functional penalty. For much of the history of FRC, motor count was limited to 16 or less, so using 8 motors in the drive often meant going without some other robot function.)

sticky_1629:

If you were to have a dead module that you couldnt fix in time you could swap an omni wheel onto the module and that would allow the robot to be somewhat driveable.

We do, in fact, carry a 4" omni wheel with installed bearings for exactly this purpose. We used it last year when we had a swerve unit go down due to a damaged Falcon (we’d whacked it into the high bar while climbing) that we didn’t have time to change before a match. It essentially makes the swerve unit into a dummy that can follow along with the other three and not impede them. It’s not as good as running on all four, of course, but it will do as an emergency fix until you can repair or replace the unit.

I’m excited to see this. I thought of this concept a while ago and it has some interesting advantages (and debilitating drawbacks). Most of the advantages have disappeared since excellent COTS modules, codebases and brushless motors emerged but all-omni swerve still lets you do some neat stuff.

If there’s a team that’s got an extra swerve drivetrain and some time in the offseason, this is (IMO) a really interesting and fun learning opportunity.

pic: OmniSwerve chassis Bottom View and Concept Discussion CD-Media: Photos
Force vectors add. Velocity vectors do not. Rather they are constrained by slip conditions and the relative motion of bodies. It’s sort of a continuously variable transmission. Say you are constrained to go in a direction 0 (by a wall or omnis opposing each other, etc.), but an omni wheel is pointed in a direction theta relative to your heading, and spinning at speed w about its axis. The overall translation velocity vector v is identically the velocity of the center of the wheel relative t…

At one competition, just to mess with Pit Admin, we took our spare, custom swerve module and put it in another team’s pit in a very prominent location. We then went to pit admin with a “parts request”. They announced it over the PA and about 10 minutes later the team whose pit we had put the module in brought it to our pit. We all got a good laugh. I’m not completely sure Pit Admin even knew what they were asking for.

If @Strategic had not already posted that they actually have such a thing as a spare omni-swerve, this would have been the next level Pit Admin prank.

“If you were better you’d understand”

Guess we’re not worthy of Omni Swerve. Shame on us filthy traction peasants needing friction to move across the floor. If you just ‘get gud’, turn on cheats, you can just ignore physics and enable no-clip. Id do it myself Just don’t wanna risk the vac ban. My dad’s cousin’s neighbor read a BuzzFeed article about it once. They had to take it down for public safety. /s

I was just thinking about this today, and if done well, this type of drivetrain would be incredibly powerful. It would allow the robot to basically skate around the field, by turning the wheels sideways, the robot could coast while using no power. Having the wheels coast like this allows the swerve to do the equivalent of changing it’s gear ratio, by angling its wheels toward each other while driving forward. If done well, an Omni Swerve robot would be incredible to watch. I really hope this becomes a reality.
